newsitem.title: USA: Healthdyne seeking alternatives to Invacare bid.
newsitem.headline: Healthdyne seeking alternatives to Invacare bid.

text.p: Healthdyne Technologies Inc. said Monday that it was actively pursuing alternatives to a hostile takeover bid by Invacare Corp. after a federal judge denied an Invacare request to overturn part of Healthdyne's shareholder rights plan, or "poison pill."
"While nothing is certain, we hope to announce a value enhancing transaction in the next several weeks," said Parker Petit, chairman of Marietta, Ga.-based Healthdyne.
Invacare has launched a $200 million hostile bid for Healthdyne, which the maker of advanced medical devices has repeatedly rejected as inadequate.

A federal judge in Atlanta ruled last Thursday that Invacare, a medical equipment manufacturer, had failed to prove it would suffer irreparable harm if the preliminary injunction it sought was not issued.
Elyria, Ohio-based Invacare had sought the preliminary injunction to invalidate the portion of the pill known as a "continuing directors," or "deadhand" provision.
The provision prohibits a new slate of directors from overturning Healthdyne's poison pill, which makes it prohibitively expensive for an investor to amass more than 5 percent of the company.
Invacare, which argued that the Healthdyne provision is illegal, has launched a proxy fight to install its own directors in order to take control of the company and abolish the poision pill.
"Now, Invacare, even if it wins the proxy contest, can't eliminate our shareholder rights plan to facilitate its grossly inadequate tender offer," Pettit said in a statement.
"We believe Judge Cooper's ruling enhances the ability of our board of directors to continue to increase shareholder value."
Healthdyne stock rose 50 cents to $17.125 and Invacare was unchanged at $23.125 early on Nasdaq.
